page.title: 17TREES IN KETTLEWELL
page.content: There are some fine specimens of trees in the village, many attracting amateur and professional artists. On the hillsides, if there is a convenient wall, the ash grows well, although in the open and on the limestone screes it can be barked by grazing sheep. There is hazel, bird-cherry and rowan, with scrubby hawthorn on dry ground. Evidence can be found of earlier coppicing of hazel, and recent conservation policy is re-introducing woodland coppicing. On the Knipe there is a section of ancient woodland, with low growing bushes, mainly hazel, but some oak and hawthorn, probably dating from the Middle Ages. The National Park, working in co-operation with local landowners have planted several areas, mainly near the screes, with specimen trees.
